name.ingredients: 500g mutton (goat or lamb, cut into pieces), 1/2 cup plain yogurt, 1 tablespoon ginger-garlic paste, 1 teaspoon red chili powder, 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder, 1 teaspoon ground coriander, 1 teaspoon garam masala, 1 tablespoon lemon juice, Salt to taste, 2 cups basmati rice (washed and soaked for 30 minutes), 4 cups water, 2-3 cloves, 2-3 green cardamom pods,1 bay leaf, 1 cinnamon stick, 2 large onions, thinly sliced, 2 tomatoes, chopped, 2 green chilies (optional), 1 tablespoon ginger-garlic paste, 1 teaspoon cumin seeds, 1/2 cup chopped mint leaves, 1/2 cup chopped coriander leaves, 1/2 teaspoon saffron strands (soaked in 2 tablespoons warm milk), 3 tablespoons ghee or oil,1/4 cup fried onions (for garnish)
instructions: In a large bowl, mix yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, red chili powder, turmeric, ground coriander, garam masala, lemon juice, and salt.  Add the mutton pieces, coat well, and marinate for at least 1-2 hours (preferably overnight).

Heat ghee or oil in a pressure cooker or heavy-bottomed pan. Add cumin seeds and let them crackle. Add sliced onions and saut√© until golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies, cooking until the raw smell disappears. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until the oil starts separating from the mixture. Add the marinated mutton and cook on medium heat for 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally. Add water and pressure cook for 20-25 minutes until the mutton is tender. If using a regular pan, cook for 45-60 minutes until the meat is soft.
In a large pot, bring water to a boil. Add cloves, cardamom, bay leaf, cinnamon stick, and salt. Add the soaked rice and cook until 70% done (the rice should still have a bite). Drain and set aside.

In a large heavy-bottomed pot, start layering the cooked mutton and rice. Spread half of the mutton at the bottom, followed by a layer of rice.Sprinkle mint leaves, coriander leaves, saffron milk, and fried onions. Repeat with the remaining mutton and rice. Finish with a final layer of rice, saffron milk, mint, coriander, and fried onions.

Cover the pot tightly with a lid or seal with dough to trap steam. Place the pot on low heat for 20-30 minutes to allow the Flavors to blend. You can also place the pot on a tawa (griddle) to prevent direct heat from burning the bottom layer.
Fluff the rice and mutton gently before serving. Serve hot with raita or a side salad.
